required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on April 10, 2017
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Retrospective Database Assessment of Clinical Effectiveness in Type 2 Diabetes Patients Treated With Liraglutide From Primary Care Centers in Sweden
clinical_study.official_title: A Retrospective Database Assessment of Clinical Effectiveness in Type 2 Diabetes Patients Treated With Liraglutide From Primary Care Centers in Sweden

brief_summary.textblock: This trial is conducted in Europe. The aim of this study is to investigate a retrospective database assessment of clinical effectiveness in type 2 diabetes patients treated with liraglutide from primary care centers in Sweden.

primary_outcome.measure: Percent (%) of patients achieving at least 1 %-point HbA1c (glycosylated haemoglobin) reduction

secondary_outcome.measure: Percent (%) of patients with HbA1c (glycosylated haemoglobin) reduction at least 1 %-point and weight reduction at least 3% (NICE clinical guidelines, liraglutide only)
Change in blood pressure (systolic, in mmHg)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline to 180 days of therapy

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in lipids (HDL, LDL and triglycerides, in mmol/L)

study_pop.textblock: Data will be analyzed for patients with type 2 diabetes treated with liraglutide or sitagliptin from January 2010 to December 2013, with a treatment length of 180 days.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients from EMR (electronic medical record) system in the primary care in Sweden
- Patients equal to or more than 18 years of age
- Starting treatment with liraglutide or sitagliptin from January 2010 to December 2013
- Minimum of 180 days of prior follow-up/history within the database before their index date
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients with cancer, end stage liver disease, end stage renal failure (non-diabetes related)
- Female patients with gestational diabetes during pregnancy
- Patients with previous GLP-1 (glucagon-like peptide-1) or DPP-IV (dipeptidyl peptidase-4 ) inhibitor use, i.e. patients should be incretin naïve
